de.uni.bamberg.wiai.minf.forflow.datagenerator.controller.datageneration.filltype
Class Editor

java.lang.Object
  de.uni.bamberg.wiai.minf.forflow.datagenerator.controller.datageneration.filltype.Editor
All Implemented Interfaces:
FillBehaviour, ObservableFillBehaviour
public class Editor
extends java.lang.Object
implements FillBehaviour

The editor filling type is a fast and handy option when no flat file exits, no interval can be defined and no pre-defined generator fits. The editor offers the option to create a list of values in the system itself, rather to switch the application an create one. It's more of convenience. It's also possible to save the entered text and link it with the external file option.

Example
Here is an example how to enter the values for an attribute (facet). Each line holds one value, it doesn't matter how long the line is or how it is written.

Notice, the class implements FillBehaviour interface. It makes this kind of strategy observable.

Observable
Observable means in this context, whenever an observer registers to or un-registers from this class, the subject itself notifies the UI to register this class in a specific list of generators.

Since:
Apr/29/09
Version:
0.1
Author:
Michael Munz

Method Detail

setValues

public void setValues(java.util.List<java.lang.String> values)
sets the values which has been typed in by the editor. Notice, this method awaits the complete list at once. Calls calulateN() to get the latest update on it.

Parameters:
values - the list of possible values

isValueIncremented

public void isValueIncremented(boolean increment)
sometimes it is useful to increment one value rather than typing in a whole bunch of different ones.

When to use?
This is especially true, when file names are generated. In the file system are usually files containing the same file name but have different version numbers, as an example. This is simulated with the increment option.

Example
Here is a quick example on how the values in the editor are used. Suppose you've typed in something like this:
Presentation_
Order
Contract with Certkiller.com

Furthermore, we assume the increment function has been enabled. The generated values for the 1st increment and the last will be:
Presentation_0
Order0
Contract with Certkiller.com 0
...
Presentation_n
Ordern
Contract with Certkiller.com n

There is still one thing to mention. Only those values will be incremented which are actually taken for generation. When available?
The option is only available when the editor is used as the fill behaviour. If you save the typed in values as an value file and then link it with external file the option will not be available anymore.

Parameters:
increment - enable function incrementing values?

isValueIncremented

public final boolean isValueIncremented()
sometimes it is useful to increment one value rather than typing in a whole bunch of different ones.

When to use?
This is especially true, when file names are generated. In the file system are usually files containing the same file name but have different version numbers, as an example. This is simulated with the increment option.

Returns:

getValueAt

public final java.lang.String getValueAt(int n)
Description copied from interface: FillBehaviour
this method has the job of retrieving the value at the specified index. Most fill behaviour strategies are based on value files. These files have a specific amount of possible values from i = 1, ..., n where i is the index. When the process of generating test data is activated, to each facet values of the fill behaviour are used. To get values in the range of the value file, this method is needed. By the way, only the strategies itselves have access to value files.

Specified by:
getValueAt in interface FillBehaviour
Parameters:
n - the index specifies the value at position n to retrieve.
Returns:
the value at position n or null

getValues

public final java.util.List<java.lang.String> getValues()
gets the list of values at once. Notice, if the list hasn't been initialized, yet, then null will be returned.

Returns:
list of typed in values

calculateN

public final int calculateN(java.net.URI file)
this method is not used here and therefore throws an UnsupportedOperationException. There exits an alternative method doing the job for editors.

Specified by:
calculateN in interface FillBehaviour
Parameters:
file - the path to the file to calc the values
Returns:
N = Σn_i
See Also:
calculateN()

getN

public final int getN()
Description copied from interface: FillBehaviour
each filling behaviour whether it is via a value file, an interval or by editor each of them has a range of values. This range is referred to as N. N is the total number of possible or available values to use for generation.

Example
Imagine having a value file called names.txt. The file has in total about 300 names, so as a result N = 300; Each of those values n = 1, ..., N gets a probability value later when it comes to probability distributions. A particular probability density function is laid over the values.

Probability density function
As an example we assume the Uniform probability distribution is used. The probability density function is for all values constant. In other words, each values is equal likely. P(X=x) = 1/N. 
 f(x)
  |
  |
  |------------ (1/N)
  |
  |
  |___________|______
              N    values

Specified by:
getN in interface FillBehaviour
Returns:
number of values N = Σn_i for this filling behaviour.

notifyOberverFillBehaviour
